title: 104_hr992
content:
The "Food Stamp Trafficking Prevention and Penalty Act of 1995" requires biennial reauthorization of retail food stores and wholesale food concerns. Documentation including tax documents and business licenses is now required for these establishments. Civil and criminal forfeiture of property is also addressed in the Act. SEC. 24. CIVIL AND CRIMINAL FORFEITURE of property under the Food Stamp Act of 1977. In cases of violations of subsection (b) or (c) of section 15, certain properties are subject to forfeiture to the United States in civil or criminal proceedings, including used coupons and conveyances like aircraft, vehicles, or vessels used to transport or facilitate illegal activities. No conveyance used in illegal activities shall be forfeited unless the owner was involved in the violation. The owner can prove innocence if the illegal act was committed by someone else while the conveyance was unlawfully in their possession. Additionally, the conveyance shall not be forfeited to the extent of the owner's interest. All books, records, and assets used in violation of specific sections shall be forfeited, including money, securities, and items exchanged for coupons. All real property, including any right, title, and interest in land used to commit a violation punishable by more than one year's imprisonment, shall be forfeited, except for the owner's interest if the owner was unaware of the violation. Any property subject to forfeiture under subsection (a) may be seized by the Attorney General under certain conditions, including incidents related to arrests, search warrants, or administrative inspections. The Attorney General can seize property under certain conditions, including a prior judgment in favor of the United States, probable danger to health or safety, or potential civil forfeiture. Seizure may lead to prompt legal proceedings. Criminal forfeiture can occur during sentencing. During sentencing for certain violations, the court can order the forfeiture of property to the United States. The Attorney General has custody of seized property and can seal it, relocate it, or transfer custody to the General Services Administration. The Attorney General has custody of seized property and can remove it to an appropriate location for disposition in accordance with the law. Other laws relating to seizure, forfeiture, and disposition of property apply to seizures and forfeitures incurred under this section. The Attorney General has custody of seized property and can remove it for disposition. Forfeited property can be retained for official use, transferred to other agencies, or sold. The Attorney General can sell forfeited property not required to be destroyed by law, transfer it to the General Services Administration for disposal, or transfer it to a foreign country with approval from the Secretary of State and in accordance with international agreements. The proceeds from any sale of forfeited property shall be used to reimburse the Department of Justice for costs incurred, and then the Department of Agriculture for any related costs. The remaining amount after reimbursing the State agency for costs incurred to assist in the proceeding shall be available to the Secretary to carry out the Act. The Attorney General must ensure that any property transferred to a State or local law enforcement agency has a value proportionate to their participation in the law enforcement effort resulting in the forfeiture. All coupons used in violation of specific sections shall be forfeited to the United States, including those seized or of unknown ownership. All property used in violation of specific sections, including those seized or of unknown ownership, shall be deemed contraband and forfeited to the United States. Title in such property vests in the United States upon commission of the act leading to forfeiture. Civil forfeiture proceedings may be stayed if related to a criminal indictment. Venue for forfeiture proceedings can be in addition to other specified locations. The Attorney General can bring forfeiture proceedings in the district where the defendant is found or where the criminal prosecution is taking place. The functions of the Attorney General under this section can be carried out by the Postal Service through an agreement. Retail food stores or wholesale food concerns can request an expedited decision regarding seized property used for their operations. The Attorney General can make a prompt determination on a petition for seized property, with rights and defenses considered. If no decision is made within 20 days, the property must be returned to the owner. The Attorney General has the authority to deny the petition and keep the property, or grant the petition and dismiss the case. The Attorney General can promptly determine a petition for seized property, with rights and defenses considered. If no decision is made within 20 days, the property must be returned to the owner. The Attorney General has the authority to deny the petition and keep the property, or grant the petition and dismiss the case. Regulations will be prescribed to carry out this process. The head of the department or agency seizing property must provide written notice to the owner and interested parties, specifying the legal basis of the seizure. The Attorney General must file a complaint for forfeiture within 60 days of a claim being filed, with the option for extension under certain circumstances. The court shall order the return of property to a store or concern if the Attorney General does not file a complaint for forfeiture. Retail or wholesale food businesses can obtain release of property by providing a bond to the Attorney General, unless the property is deemed contraband, evidence of a violation, or suited for illegal activities. Section 15 of the Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended by removing subsection (g) related to illegal activities. The effective dates for the amendments in this Act are as follows: 
- Sections 2 and 3 will take effect 60 days after enactment. 
- Section 4 amendments will take effect immediately upon enactment.
